awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Ultra-Thin, Cooling Solutions for High Performance, Mobile Communications
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to apply the novel ultra-thin cooling technology beyond just mobile phones toward multiple mobile platforms in the communications sector ? an area with several large, multi-billion dollar markets, including tablets and ultrabooks.  With the novel technology's modular, scalable design for ease in manufacturing and bendability for mounting into ultra-thin, tight spaces, the platform can also be adapted for use in routers and other telecommunications hardware platforms.  With data centers, which are already shifting towards using mobile chip technologies to increase energy efficiency and lower cost, this novel cooling technology, once proven in mobile phones, stands to be adopted in this market as well.  Overall, multiple markets are in need of ultra-thin, high performance, but low cost thermal solutions which the cooling technology being developed will be able to address broadening its impact as a thermal management technology.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project works toward solving major problems in thermal management for mobile chip sets with novel, ultra-thin cooling technology, the initial prototypes which will be developed in Phase I.  Current chipsets do not produce excessive amounts of heat (less than 10W), but their location deep within the phone, and proximity to plastic components with low thermal conductivity, makes it difficult to dissipate heat.  The cooling technology being ultra-thin at 500 um or less and with the ability to be modularly integrated with the unique characteristic of needing little to no changes to current phone topology is ideal for mobile applications.  It can connect with hard to reach hot chips, move heat long distances, and evenly distribute heat along a low conductivity back plate or case.  To maintain comfort for device users, cooling technology being developed would limit temperatures to 45°C at maximum performance, while still being able to dissipate heat to ambient conditions, such as a hand or pants pocket at around 30 degrees celsius.

por.por_cntn:
ChillFlux’s NSF SBIR Phase I proposal called for the design and prototyping of a loop heat pipe to provide a better thermal management solution for cell phones and compact frequent use devices. A heat pipe dissipates heat as if it were a very efficient conducting material; it does this by using phase change to maximize heat transfer. This behavior makes it an ideal tool for future electronics applications where as more heat is produced in concentrated areas, even the most thermally conductive materials cannot spread or remove the amount of heat being produced.

The FLEXS chips were designed to function with some of the same basic principles as other heat pipes - there is a condenser area and an evaporator area with liquid and vapor circulation between the two. The liquid transport is capillary driven and follows the general principles of the Laplace-Young equation and Darcy's law. The innovations developed in this work focus around new evaporator structures, new fabrication techniques common to other industries (but never used this way before), and a new type of circulation and layout. These advancements increase device efficiency and allow this technology to outperform competitors, while remaining thin and bendable.    

The aims of the proposal were to create a competitive device that operates with no input power, is 0.5mm thick and can handle 6W of dissipation at room temperature.  To meet the goal of fabricating devices with a total thickness of 0.5mm, several iterations were necessary over the course of this Phase I grant. Initially the devices were shrunk from 2mm to 1mm and then ultimately from 0.65mm to 0.48mm.  These devices were shown to have maximum input power of 6 W; a thicker version of the device was able to absorb even higher power.  In addition to fabricating these thin devices, this project aimed to fabricate and demonstrate devices that can be bent to fit around the internal geometry of electronic devices. The 0.48mm devices were bent to specified bend radii and were successfully tested.  The final thinning and testing of bent devices resulted in a set of final prototype devices that are being actively shown and demonstrated to potential investors and customers with great interest.

The findings of the research conducted during the SBIR Phase I grant period show that the technology proposed by the ChillFlux team is viable and has performance characteristics that make it competitive in the market. This grant has allowed the team to take the idea from concept to prototype within a short amount of time. In less than a year, the FLEXS technology has been proven to dissipate 6 times the heat of its competitors, in a thinner form factor. There is a path forward to create multiple versions of this device that are competitive in several markets outside of mobile. The thin devices that dissipate at least 5.5W of heat could be used in telecom or smartphone applications and the data indicates that future iterations could be thinned to 0.3mm with minimal changes to the current design.  There is also the potential for 1mm thick devices that can dissipate 10W or more.  These could outperform more conventional thermal solutions and open up new markets with additional development. Working devices that meet the criteria set forth by the Phase I goals were produced, but importantly, additional data has also shown a huge realm of possibilities surrounding this work that start with the smartphone industry and branch out from there. The potential for this technology provides ChillFlux with the opportunity to create a growth-oriented business.
